company.name: Superior Mortgage Corporation
company.business_description: Superior Mortgage Corp. is a direct lender that specializes in residential mortgage loans. It conducts business through its headquarters in Tuckerton, forty (40) branch offices located in ten different states, and six separate websites.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45; Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule ('Safeguards Rule'), 16 C.F.R. Part 314, issued pursuant to Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

complaint.factual_background: Superior Mortgage Corporation, a direct lender specializing in residential mortgage loans, violated the FTC's Safeguards Rule by failing to implement reasonable security policies and procedures to protect sensitive customer information from May 2003 until at least May 2005. The company also falsely represented on its website that personal information was encrypted using SSL from submission until receipt, when in fact the information was decrypted and emailed in clear, readable text once it reached the server operated by a service provider outside the company's computer network.

representations_made.description: Claimed that all information submitted through the website was encrypted using SSL encryption
representations_made.quoted_text: All information submitted is handled by SSL encryption ­ see the yellow padlock at the bottom of your browser.

representations_made.description: Represented that personal information obtained from consumers was encrypted using SSL from the time of submission until receipt by respondent
representations_made.quoted_text: Through the means described in paragraph 11, respondent has represented, expressly or by implication, that the personal information it obtained from consumers through www.supmort.com was encrypted using SSL from the time of submission until receipt by respondent.

counts.title: Violations of the Safeguards Rule
counts.representation: Respondent was required to implement reasonable security policies and procedures under the Safeguards Rule, including identifying risks, designing and implementing safeguards, and overseeing service providers
counts.fact: Respondent failed to (a) assess risks to customer information until more than a year after the Rule's effective date; (b) institute appropriate password policies; (c) encrypt or otherwise protect sensitive customer information emailed outside its network; (d) identify reasonably foreseeable internal and external risks; (e) design, implement, test and monitor information safeguards; and (f) oversee service providers to ensure they implement safeguards
counts.conclusion: By failing to implement reasonable security policies and procedures, respondent engaged in violations of the Safeguards Rule, which constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: False SSL Encryption Representation
counts.representation: Respondent represented that personal information obtained from consumers through www.supmort.com was encrypted using SSL from the time of submission until receipt by respondent
counts.fact: The personal information was only encrypted using SSL while being transmitted between a visitor's web browser and the website's server; once the information reached the server operated by a service provider outside of respondent's computer network, it was decrypted and emailed to respondent's headquarters and branch offices in clear, readable text
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in paragraph 12 was false or misleading, constituting unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act.

definitions.Personal information: individually identifiable information from or about an individual consumer including, but not limited to: (a) a first and last name; (b) a home or other physical address, including street name and name of city or town; (c) an email address or other online contact information, such as an instant messaging user identifier or a screen name that reveals an individual's email address; (d) a telephone number; (e) a Social Security number; (f) a credit history; (g) a bank or credit card account number; or (h) any other information from or about an individual consumer that is combined with (a) through (g) above.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.
definitions.Respondent: Superior Mortgage Corp., its successors and assigns and its officers, agents, representatives, and employees.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent the extent to which personal information is protected by SSL encryption or the extent to which it maintains privacy, confidentiality, or security of personal information.

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent SSL encryption protection of personal information
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondent, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, in connection with the advertising, marketing, promotion, offering for sale, or sale of any product or service, in or affecting commerce, shall not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication, (a) the extent to which personal information submitted by consumers through respondent's websites is protected by SSL encryption

requirements.description: Must not misrepresent privacy, confidentiality, or security of personal information
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS ORDERED that respondent, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, or other device, in connection with the advertising, marketing, promotion, offering for sale, or sale of any product or service, in or affecting commerce, shall not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication, (b) the extent to which respondent maintains and protects the privacy, confidentiality, or security of any personal information collected from or about consumers.

provisions.title: Compliance with Safeguards Rule
provisions.summary: Respondent must not violate any provision of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule.

requirements.description: Must comply with the GLB Act Safeguards Rule
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall not, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or otherdevice,violateanyprovision of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's ("GLB Act") Standards for SafeguardingCustomerInformationRule("Safeguards Rule"), 16 C.F.R. Part 314.

provisions.title: Third-Party Biennial Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain independent third-party security assessments within 180 days and biennially thereafter for 10 years, certifying compliance with the Safeguards Rule.

requirements.description: Obtain initial third-party assessment within 180 days
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that, in connection with its compliance with the Safeguards Rule, respondent shall obtain an assessment and report (an "Assessment") from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional, using procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession, within one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of the order

requirements.description: Obtain biennial assessments for 10 years after service of order
requirements.quoted_text: respondent shall obtain an assessment and report (an "Assessment") from a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional, using procedures and standards generally accepted in the profession, within one hundred and eighty (180) days after service of the order, and biennially thereafter for ten (10) years after service of the order
sets forth the specific administrative, technical, and physical safeguards that respondent has implemented and maintained during the reporting period

requirements.description: Assessment must explain appropriateness of safeguards
requirements.quoted_text: explains how such safeguards are appropriate to respondent's size and complexity, the nature and scope of respondent's activities, and the sensitivity of the nonpublic personal information collected from or about consumers

requirements.description: Assessment must explain compliance with Safeguards Rule
requirements.quoted_text: explains how such safeguards meet or exceed the protections required by the Safeguards Rule

requirements.description: Assessment must certify security program effectiveness
requirements.quoted_text: certifies that respondent's security program is operating with sufficient effectiveness to provide reasonable assurance that the security, confidentiality, and integrity of nonpublic personal information is protected and, for biennial reports, has so operated throughout the reporting period.

requirements.description: Assessment must be prepared by qualified security professional
requirements.quoted_text: Each Assessment shall be prepared by a person qualified as a Certified Information System Security Professional (CISSP); a person qualified as a Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA); a person holding Global Information Assurance Certification (GIAC) from the SysAdmin, Audit, Network, Security Institute (SANS); or by a similarly qualified person or organization approved by the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission.

requirements.description: Provide first assessment and supporting materials to FTC within 10 days of preparation
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall provide the first Assessment, as well as all plans, reports, studies, reviews, audits, audit trails, policies, training materials, and assessments, whether prepared by or on behalf of respondent, relied upon to prepare such Assessment to the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, Washington, D.C. 20580, within ten (10) days after the Assessment has been prepared.

requirements.description: Retain subsequent assessments until order termination
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall retain all subsequent biennial Assessments until the order is terminated and shall retain all materials relied upon in preparing each such Assessment, as listed above, for a period of three (3) years after the date of preparation of such Assessment.

requirements.description: Provide subsequent assessments to FTC within 10 days of request
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall provide such subsequent Assessments and related materials to the Associate Director of Enforcement within ten (10) days of request.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Distribution
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future managers and supervisory personnel within 30 days.

requirements.description: Deliver order to current supervisory personnel within 30 days
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having supervisory responsibilities with respect to the subject matter of this order. Respondent shall deliver this order to such current personnel within thirty (30) days after the date of service of this order

requirements.description: Deliver order to future supervisory personnel within 30 days of assuming position
requirements.quoted_text: Respondent shall deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current and future employees, agents, and representatives having supervisory responsibilities with respect to the subject matter of this order. Respondent shall deliver this order to such future personnel within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the Commission at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations.

requirements.description: Notify FTC 30 days prior to corporate changes affecting compliance
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the corporation that may affect compliance obligations arising under this order, including, but not limited to, a dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this order; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address.

requirements.description: Notify FTC as soon as practicable if change is learned less than 30 days in advance
requirements.quoted_text: Provided, however, that, with respect to any proposed change in the corporation about which respondent learns less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, respondent shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report with the Commission within 180 days and at other times as required.

requirements.description: File compliance report within 180 days including initial assessment
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that respondent shall within one hundred eighty (180) days after service of this order, and at such other times as the Federal Trade Commission may require, file with the Commission a report, in writing, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which it has complied with this order. This report shall include a copy of the initial biennial Assessment required by Part III of this order.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order will terminate on December 14, 2025, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging violation of the order, whichever is later.

requirements.description: Order terminates on December 14, 2025, or 20 years from most recent complaint filing, whichever is later
requirements.quoted_text: This order will terminate on December 14, 2025, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later

duration.termination_text: This order will terminate on December 14, 2025, or twenty (20) years from the most recent date that the United States or the Federal Trade Commission files a complaint (with or without an accompanying consent decree) in federal court alleging any violation of the order, whichever comes later; provided, however, that the filing of such a complaint will not affect the duration of: A. Any Part in this order that terminates in less than twenty (20) years; B. This order's application to any respondent that is not named as a defendant in such complaint; and C. This order if such complaint is filed after the order has terminated pursuant to this Part. Provided, further, that if such complaint is dismissed or a federal court rules that the respondent did not violate any provision of the order, and the dismissal or ruling is either not appealed or upheld on appeal, then the order will terminate according to this Part as though the complaint had never been filed, except that the order will not terminate between the date such complaint is filed and the later of the deadline for appealing such dismissal or ruling and the date such dismissal or ruling is upheld on appeal.
